title: Dad in ‘Ocean’s Eleven’ heist says being arrested was ‘best thing to happen’
text:
Terry used to dress as a policeman to steal millions at a time (Picture: Terry Ellis)

A dad of five who stole millions in ‘Ocean’s Eleven’ heists says getting arrested was the ‘best thing to ever happen to him’.

Terry Ellis, 54, fell into a life of crime when he was a teenager and would dress as a policeman to steal goods worth up to £4 million at a time.

But after 28 years of crime, the armed robber was finally caught by police while on the run and forced to confess all to his children.

He has now completely turned his life around and is supporting a new campaign called More Than My Past that aims to show that ex-offenders and recovering addicts are ‘more than the labels provided to them’.

Terry was put into care when he was 11, but was removed when he got a girl pregnant at 14.

Authorities ‘washed their hands’ of him and he spent the next five years stealing money from building sites and post offices after getting involved with a group of older men he shared a London flat with.

Terry told Metro.co.uk: ‘These were the people I looked up to. They were older, they had money, they looked after me.

‘Everyone I met was a criminal, so I normalised criminality. It was good to do robberies and get away with it.

He has now dedicated his life to helping young people who find themselves in the same situation he was once in (Picture: More Than My Past)

‘It was only bad if you got caught, so you learned not to get caught.’

After spending six years in a young offenders institution for robbery, Terry’s crimes escalated and he spent years trafficking drugs across Europe and partying 24/7.

With a crime squad hot on his heels, he was forced to briefly stop, but soon enough he’d come up with a plan to steal more money than ever.

‘Ocean’s Eleven’ heists saw him and four others disguise themselves as policemen and head to bonded warehouses to trick guards.

Speaking about one heist in Kings Cross, Terry said: ‘We just walked through the front door wearing police uniforms with some ID and we took our own ‘police’ dogs.

‘We said we’d been informed there was a robbery and someone was getting in through the roof.

‘They let us in and we told them we’d like to cuff everyone until we found out who it was.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘After we cuffed them, we nicked about £4 million pounds worth of motherboards computer chips.’

But after years of making millions, the robber’s lies finally crashed down on him.

In 2008, he was walking down a ‘quiet road’ that ‘came alive’ with police who arrested him.

His house was raided and he was forced to confess his crimes to his teenage children, who had believed their dad had a ‘normal’ job.

The 54-year-old has now founded a platform for the people of Camden to tackle violence (Picture: Terry Ellis)

He said: ‘It was a pretty traumatic time for the girls. They just saw me as their dad who provided and went out to work every day, never had a clue what I was doing.

‘My biggest regret is not being there for them and not being the father they thought I was. That comes back to haunt me quite a bit.’

Terry was sentenced to 16 years in prison, but despite his burgeoning regret, he still tried to escape and took on eight officers in a brutal fight.

He said: ‘In my head there were two voices, one wanting to get away and one saying ‘stop it, you’re caught now’.

‘There was this bad part of me that was really reckless and didn’t give a monkey’s.’

The dad finally found peace when he was sent to HMP Grendon in Buckinghamshire, the only prison in the UK run entirely as a democratic therapeutic community.

After spending two years in therapy alongside child murderers, sex offenders and serial killers, he finally dealt with his issues.

Terry’s campaigns against knife crime have led him to meet politicians like Jeremy Corbyn (Picture: Terry Ellis)

He said: ‘That was the moment I realised I’d normalised going to prison, normalised going into care, normalised my life, but I was actually quite a messed up individual.

Advertisement

‘As I talked, I felt a little bit of relief, understanding.’

‘After therapy, I didn’t need to take drugs anymore. I’m now 14 years without drink, drugs, cigarettes and still counting every day as a blessing.

‘That’s really just from understanding who I was. I think you have to become a victim before you can deal with your troubles. I found me for the first time.’

After spending 15 years of his life in custody overall, Terry left prison and was helped back on his feet by loved ones.

He has since set up his own social enterprise to help ex-offenders to find jobs, founded a platform for the people of Camden to tackle violence and runs the Camden branch of charity A Band of Brothers that provides mentors for young men in the criminal justice system.

The former armed robber also supports More Than My Past, a campaign that aims to challenge the stigma ex-offenders and recovering addicts – who are the two groups that organisations are least likely to employ – find themselves up against.

Terry says he’s never once missed his life of crime and advises young people in his situation to pick their role models wisely.

He said: ‘Don’t pick someone who’s a villain, who’s doing the easy money.

‘Pick someone like your dad who’s working, pick someone like the school teacher, the fireman, the policeman and try to educate yourself out of the mess.’

‘Remember, if you sleep with dogs, you’re going to get fleas.’

description: Terry Ellis, a father of five who stole millions in ‘Ocean’s Eleven’ heists says getting arrested was the 'best thing to ever happen'.
